The Master of Wen Shi was styled so in the Zhou, and titled *Wei Bian* in the celestial ranks.

*The New Record of the Cinnabar Terrace* states: Yin Xi initially served as the magistrate of Hangu Pass. One day, he saw an old man riding a blue ox, drawing near in a humble carriage. Xi prostrated himself and approached, asking, "Where does the Sage intend to go?" The old man replied, "My home lies east of the pass, my fields west of it. I come now and then to gather firewood. I possess no virtue or power, yet you trouble yourself to inquire." Though the old man declined repeatedly, Xi persisted. Finally, the old man said, "Since you know the Five, I also know you harbor a heart faithful to the Dao." Thereupon, he bestowed upon Xi the *Scripture of the Dao and Its Virtue*. Xi’s cultivation perfected, his virtue complete, he was styled Master Wen Shi and appointed as the Supreme Perfected.

*The Declarations of the Perfected* records: Zhuang Zhou studied under Master Chang Sang, who transmitted to him subtle teachings, whence he became known as Zhuangzi. He concealed himself on Mount Baodu, refining his practice and composing texts. Having ingested the Northern Nurturing Fire Elixir, he ascended to heaven in broad daylight, where he was appointed as the *Wei Bian* Gentleman of the Supreme Ultimate.

Xuan Ji transmitted the leaf, Ma Xiang grasped the coin.

*The Lives of Eminent Daoists* recounts: Master Xuan Yuan Ji of Mount Luofu dwelled on the mountain for several centuries, his complexion unaged, his hair trailing to the ground. In darkened chambers, his gaze stretched for yards. When he ventured into cliffs and valleys to gather herbs, poisonous dragons and fierce beasts guarded him. Over a hundred households invited him to vegetarian feasts, and he appeared at each without fail. Emperor Xuanzong summoned him to the palace and asked, "Can longevity be governed?" Ji replied, "Sever sensual indulgence, moderate rich flavors, regulate joy and sorrow as one, and bestow virtue without partiality. Naturally, you will unite with heaven and earth in virtue, match the sun and moon in brilliance. Even Yao, Shun, Yu, and Tang could attain this—how much more so longevity?" The master could press paulownia or bamboo leaves into coins.

*The Traditions of Divine Transcendents* states: Ma Xiang, styled Ziran, possessed Daoist arts. Once, at the seat of Governor Ma Zhi of Jiangnan, he filled a wine cup with soil and planted melon seeds. In an instant, vines sprouted, flowers bloomed, and fruit ripened—its taste was exquisite. He could also shrink his body, pluck green coins, and cast them into a well, summoning them forth at will.

The numinous chariot and blessed land, the mountain chart and grotto-heaven.

*The Lives of Eminent Daoists* records: Wang Lingyu, a Daoist of Jiujiang, resided on the Five Elders Peak. One night, a divine person told him, "Those who attain the Dao each have their proper place, just as planting the five grains in sand and stone yields no harvest. Since you possess the bones of a flying transcendent, you must find a blessed land and numinous abode to achieve transformation. Without it, demons will disrupt your practice, and your aspirations will come to naught." The master asked, "Where may I dwell?" The divine person replied, "The summit of Vermilion Mound, the neighboring peak of Purple Canopy—these are a grotto-heaven and blessed land, where you may ascend to heaven." The master followed this advice and relocated to Mount Heng. After twelve years, his work complete, he ascended in broad daylight during the Tianjian era.

*The Declarations of the Perfected* states: The Mountain Chart Master was a grandee during the reign of King Ai of Zhou and also a transcendent. He transmitted the Nine Cloud Water Method to Zhang Jizi, who cultivated this Way and was appointed as the Assistant of the Nine Palaces. Now, the Mountain Chart Master dwells in the grotto-heaven, playing chess with Jizi.

Da Ling regrew his beard, Zhang Guo knocked out his teeth.

*The Inscription on the Wall of Chaohua Temple* records: During the Tang, the palace attendant Jian Da Ling wrote: "In the year I came to know my fate, I followed the imperial carriage on its western journey. In the twelfth month of the *dinghai* year of Tianbao, I received the True Origin Elixir Formula from the Old Man of the City, though its meaning eluded me. As the imperial progress halted and official duties pressed, I set it aside. In the *dingyou* year of Zhide under Emperor Suzong, while on a mission to Song Hill, I encountered the Old Man again and at last fully grasped the Way of Divine Water and Yellow Sprouts. Upon completion, I sought leave to return to the imperial court, then retired to my fields. Coincidentally, Minister Zhang Qufei of the Southern Bureau and Left Historian Cheng Taixu, both acquainted with my former abode, jointly prepared a sacred chamber. With the aid of spring blessings from august heaven, the elixir crucible radiated light. After ingesting the medicine for a full cycle, my flesh and complexion became radiant, my hair lustrous. I soared through the void without fear, my mind ever more attuned to the divine. From the time I first ingested the numinous elixir in the *dingyou* year of Zhide until the *jiayou* year of Qianfu under the present emperor, one hundred and eighteen years have passed. Having served twelve reigns, I have regained my youth and regrown my beard."

*The Miscellaneous Records of Emperor Ming* states: When Emperor Ming summoned Zhang Guo, he once offered him wine poured by Dong Yin. Guo drained three goblets in succession, his face flushed with intoxication. Turning to his attendants, he remarked, "This wine is not of fine quality." He then reclined outward, and after the time it takes to eat a meal, he awoke. Suddenly, he gazed into a mirror and saw his teeth mottled and blackened with decay. Seizing an iron ruyi, he struck his teeth, and they all fell out.
chunks.overlap_context: ween Han and Chu, when there was no place to find sustenance, each harbored the aspiration to cultivate the Dao. They retreated into the mountains, pledged brotherhood, and wandered together among the Five Marchmounts. Later, they dwelled on West Mountain in Hongzhou. All attained transcendence. By the Kaihuang era of the Sui, phoenixes and cranes with their ceremonial escorts gathered at Nine Transcendents Terrace on Yushun Mountain. They lingered for a day before ascending to heaven in unison.

chunks.translated_text:
He applied medicine to his teeth and again slept. After a long while, he drew the mirror to look—his teeth had regrown, firm, lustrous, and more radiant than before.

The Cock Master Cures Illness; Ao Ling Channels the Waters.
*The Idle Talks of the Military Camp* records: In Tang-era Shu, there lived a man called Fei Jishi, "Cock Master," whose eyes were red without pupils. He could foresee events and perform exorcisms for others. When someone afflicted by illness came to seek his aid, Jishi would carry a rooster to the courtyard and set up an offering. He would then take a stone the size of a chicken’s egg, place it in the patient’s hand, and stride in zigzag steps, exhaling and shouting sharply. The rooster would spin and die, the stone shatter into four pieces—and the patient’s convulsions would cease. Hence his name, Cock Master.

*The Supplementary Biographies of Transcendents* states: Ao Ling was a man of Chu who, after death, was cast into the river. His body drifted upstream to the foot of Mount Wen, where he suddenly revived and concealed himself among the mountains of Shu. His mastery of transformation and command over ghosts and spirits became widely known. At the time, landslides in the gorges had dammed the river, causing the waters to stagnate. Emperor Du Yu, distressed by this, heard of Ao Ling’s abilities and sent him to Jintang Mountain at Qutang Gorge. There, Ao Ling channeled the waters, restoring their original course so that people could once more dwell on dry land. Du Yu abdicated several hundred years later, wandering to Mount Tianzhu, where he encountered a gathering of celestial perfected. He then ascended to heaven and departed.

Xuan Ji Bestows Leaves; Ma Xiang Plucks Coins.
*The Biographies of Eminent Daoists* recounts: Master Xuan Yuan Ji of Mount Luofu was said to have lived for several centuries, his complexion unaged, his hair trailing to the ground. In dark chambers, his gaze could stretch for yards. When he ventured into the valleys to gather herbs, poisonous dragons and fierce beasts guarded him. He would visit over a hundred households to accept vegetarian offerings, yet his presence remained undivided. Emperor Xuanzong summoned him to the palace and asked, "Can one govern longevity?" The master replied, "Sever desire for sensual pleasures, moderate rich flavors, equalize sorrow and joy, and practice impartial virtue. Then you will naturally align with the power of heaven and earth, match the brightness of sun and moon. Even the sages Yao, Shun, Yu, and Tang could attain this—how much more so longevity?" The master could press paulownia or bamboo leaves into coins.

*The Biographies of Divine Transcendents* states: Ma Xiang, styled Ziran, possessed Daoist arts. Once, at the residence of the Jiangnan governor Ma Zhi, he filled a wine cup with soil and planted melon seeds. In an instant, vines sprouted, flowers bloomed, and fruit ripened—its taste was exquisite. He could also shrink his body, pluck green coins, and toss them into a well, summoning them back at will.

The Divine Chariot’s Blessed Land; The Mountain Chart’s Grotto-Heaven.
*The Biographies of Eminent Daoists* records: Wang Lingyu, a Daoist of Jiujiang, dwelled on Five Elders Peak. One night, a divine being told him, "Those who attain the Dao each have their proper place, just as planting the five grains in sand and stone will yield no harvest. Since you possess the bones of a flying transcendent, you must find a blessed land and numinous cavern. There, you may transform; elsewhere, demons will corrupt your practice, and no hope of success remains." The master asked, "Where may I dwell?" The being replied, "The upper peak of Zhu Ling, the neighboring summit of Zi Gai—these are a grotto-heaven and blessed land, where you may ascend to heaven." The master followed this advice and moved to Mount Heng. After twelve years of cultivation, during the Tianjian era, he ascended in broad daylight.

*The Declarations of the Perfected* states: Shan Tuzi was a minister during the reign of King Ai of Zhou and also a transcendent. He transmitted the method of the Ninefold Cloud Water to Zhang Jizi, who practiced this Way to ascend as an assistant to the Nine Palaces. Now, Shan Tuzi resides in the grotto-heaven, playing chess with Jizi.

Da Ling Regrows His Beard; Zhang Guo Strikes His Teeth.
*The Inscription on the Wall of Chaohua Temple* records: The Tang eunuch and palace attendant Jian Daling wrote: "In the year of my fate’s decree, I followed the imperial carriage on its western journey. In the twelfth month of the *dinghai* year of Tianbao, I received the true elixir formula from the Old Man of the City, though its meaning eluded me. As the imperial retinue halted, my duties grew burdensome. In the *dingyou* year of Zhide under Emperor Suzong, while on a mission to Song Hill, I encountered the Old Man again and at last fully grasped the Way of Divine Water and Yellow Sprouts. Upon completion, I sought leave to return to the imperial court, then retired to my fields. The Southern Bureau official Zhang Qufei and the Left Historian Cheng Taixu, both familiar with my former abode, jointly prepared a sacred chamber. With the aid of spring blessings from august heaven, the elixir crucible glowed, and after ingesting the medicine for a full cycle of days, my flesh and complexion became radiant, my hair lustrous. I soared through the void without fear, my mind ever more attuned to the divine. From the time I first ingested the numinous elixir in the *dingyou* year of Zhide until the *jiayou* year of Qianfu under the present emperor, one hundred and eighteen years have passed. Having served twelve reigns, I have regained my youth and regrown my beard."

*The Miscellaneous Records of Emperor Ming* states: When Emperor Ming summoned Zhang Guo, he once offered him wine poured by Dong Yin. Guo drained three goblets in succession, his face flushed with intoxication. Turning to his attendants, he remarked, "This wine is not of fine quality." He then reclined outward, and after the time it takes to eat a meal, he awoke. Suddenly, he gazed into a mirror and saw his teeth mottled and blackened with decay. Seizing an iron *ruyi*, he struck his teeth, and they all fell out.

chunks.original_text: 以药傅齿，又寝。 久之，再引镒视其齿已生，坚然光莹，愈於前也。 鸡师救病，鳖灵导水。 《戎幕闲谈》：唐蜀川费鸡师者，目赤无黑，善知将来事，能与人禳救，其衍或疾病来告者，鸡师即抱一鸡而往设祭於庭，又取一石如鸡卯大，令病人握之，乃歪步作气嘘叱，鸡旋转而死，石亦四破，则病者痉矣，因号鸡师云。 《仙传拾遗》：鳌灵，楚人也，死弃其户於江中，沂流而上，至汶山下，蹶然而起，隐於蜀山中，以变化驱役鬼神之衍闻於世。 时峡中山摧，堰江不流，杜宇苦之，闻鳖灵有卫，使次金堂山瞿塘峡，导水束注复旧所，人得陆处。 宇逊位数百年，游天柱山，遇天真集焉，遂升天而去。 葛由刻木，张辞剪纸。 《列仙传》：葛由，蜀人，周成王时常刻木为羊卖。 一日骑羊入蜀，王侯贵人迎之至绥山，随之者皆得一桃，不还，里人诊曰：得绥山一桃，虽不仙，亦足豪。 《广记》：张辞有才学，养气绝食，嗜酒耽棋，尝吟云：争奈金乌何，头上飞不住，红炉护烧药，玉颜安可驻。 今年花发枝，明年花满树，不如且饮酒，朝暮复朝暮。 时或以纸剪蝴蝶数千枚，以气吹之，成列而飞拍手即下。 或一日剪一鹤，以水叹之，俄而飞书，辞曰：尔先去，我后来。 马俭制邪，刘根召鬼。 《丹台新录》：马检通《诗》、《礼》，年十七遇人得遁甲乌角乌情纬候之诀，善摄召万灵，制邪伏魔。 一旦感天神降，与语曰：法师宿有功德，铃得度世，何须召役鬼神，可秘其衍，绝其往来，怡神抱一，真仙自降。 俭从之，白日上升。 《神仙传》：刘根能治病驱役，颖川太守杜新闻之，以为妖妄，因呼根至郡，谓根曰：君有何能而常惑众。 根曰：某能令人见鬼。 新曰：今即试看，若无鬼，汝当见诛。 根曰：鬼甚易见，可借府君前笔现。 新从之，根书符，作长啸声，须臾厅南壁忽开数尺，见有四五百人赤衣操刀剑，从坏壁中入至墀下，面缚府君父母而来，泣曰：汝何为犯神仙尊官，使我被缚困辱如此。 府君叩头求乞放赦，根戒敕遣之，遂免。 后一月，府君与夫人郭氏皆卒。 陈长架屋，严青挽舟。 《抱朴子》：陈长居苎莫山已六百余年，山中人为之架屋，每四时祭祀之，陈不饮不食，颜如五六十人。 苎莫山方千里，上有千余家，风俗与吴同。 又严青，会稽人，食贫贩炭，忽於涂中遇异人，授以素书一卷。 青曰：我不识字。 神人曰：不须读，但置於静处可也。 青自后神通，潜有人为挽舟而入只见炭船自行。 后为人治病，即以所授之书到家，其人自愈。 入小霍山得仙。 希夷尧舜，洪崖巢由。 《神仙传》：陈搏字图南，号希夷先生，时遇金甲神人指隐华山，太宗皇帝召见问曰：朕欲以尧舜之道治天下，可乎。 对曰：臣闻尧舜土阶三尺，茆茨不剪，陛下若能如此，正所谓今之尧舜也。 《高道传》：道士张氲号洪崖子，隐豫章山。 开元中，明皇召问：朕何如尧舜，先生何如许由。 对曰：陛下道高尧舜，臣德谢许由。 昔尧召由而由不至，今陛下召臣而臣来。 上嘉之，拜先生，太常卿累迁至司徒，皆不受，乃曰：陛下何惜一山一水，令臣追进巢由。 上许之，居於西山巨崖，乃先生旧隐之处也。 《豫章记》云：隋开皇改为洪州，以先生所居山名而名之。

Applying medicinal paste to his teeth, he then slept. After a long while, he again took up the mirror and saw that his teeth had regrown—firm, lustrous, and more radiant than before.

The Rooster Master healed the sick; Ao Ling channeled the waters.
*The Idle Talks of the Military Camp* records: In Tang-era Shu, there lived a man called Fei the Rooster Master, whose eyes were entirely red, devoid of pupils. Skilled in divining the future, he could perform exorcisms for others. When someone afflicted by illness came to seek his aid, the Rooster Master would carry a rooster to the courtyard and set up an altar. Taking a stone the size of a chicken’s egg, he would have the patient grasp it, then pace in zigzag steps, exhaling sharply and shouting incantations. The rooster would spin in circles until it died, and the stone would shatter into four pieces—whereupon the patient’s convulsions ceased. Thus he earned the name Rooster Master.

*The Supplementary Biographies of Immortals* states: Ao Ling was a man of Chu who, upon his death, was cast into the river. His body drifted upstream to the foot of Mount Wen, where he suddenly revived and concealed himself among the mountains of Shu. His mastery of transformation and command over spirits and gods became renowned. At the time, landslides had dammed the gorges, blocking the flow of the river, causing great distress to Du Yu. Hearing of Ao Ling’s abilities, Du Yu dispatched him to Jintang Mountain at Qutang Gorge to channel the waters and restore their original course, allowing people to dwell once more on dry land. Du Yu abdicated his throne and, centuries later, wandered to Mount Tianzhu, where he encountered a gathering of celestial beings. He then ascended to heaven and departed.

Ge You carved wood; Zhang Ci cut paper.
*The Biographies of the Immortals* recounts: Ge You was a man of Shu who, during the reign of King Cheng of Zhou, often carved wooden sheep to sell. One day, he rode a sheep into Shu, and the kings, marquises, and nobles welcomed him to Sui Mountain. Those who followed him each received a peach, and none returned. The villagers remarked, “To receive a peach from Sui Mountain is not to become an immortal, yet it is enough to be esteemed.”

*The Extensive Records* states: Zhang Ci was a learned man who cultivated qi and abstained from food. Fond of wine and obsessed with chess, he once composed a poem:
*What can be done about the golden crow,*
*That flies ceaselessly overhead?*
*The red furnace guards the elixir’s flame,*
*Yet how can jade-like beauty be preserved?*
*This year, flowers bloom upon the branch;*
*Next year, they cover the entire tree.*
*Better to drink wine without cease,*
*From dawn to dusk, and dawn again.*

At times, he would cut thousands of paper butterflies, blow upon them with his breath, and send them flying in formation. At his clap, they would descend. On another day, he cut a paper crane, sighed upon it with water, and suddenly it took flight. He wrote: “You go first; I will follow later.”

Ma Jian subdued evil; Liu Gen summoned ghosts.
*The New Records of the Alchemical Terrace* states: Ma Jian was well-versed in the *Book of Songs* and the *Book of Rites*. At seventeen, he encountered a master who taught him the arts of *dunjia*, the Raven’s Horn, and the Raven’s Essence, along with the secrets of celestial portents. Skilled in summoning and commanding spirits, he could subdue evil and vanquish demons. One day, a celestial deity descended and addressed him: “Master, you possess accumulated merit and are destined for transcendence. Why do you summon and command spirits? Conceal your arts, sever all ties, cultivate serenity, and embrace the One—true immortality will come of its own accord.” Ma Jian heeded this advice and ascended to heaven in broad daylight.

*The Biographies of Divine Immortals* records: Liu Gen could heal the sick and command spirits. When Du Xin, the governor of Yingchuan, heard of him, he suspected him of sorcery and summoned him to the prefectural office. “What powers do you possess,” Du Xin asked, “that you so delude the people?” Liu Gen replied, “I can make ghosts appear.” Du Xin said, “Prove it now. If no ghost appears, you will be executed.” Liu Gen replied, “Ghosts are easily summoned. Lend me your brush.” Du Xin complied. Liu Gen inscribed a talisman and let out a long whistle. In an instant, the southern wall of the hall split open several feet, and four or five hundred men in red garments, wielding swords, emerged from the breach. They bound the governor’s parents and brought them forward, weeping: “Why have you offended the divine immortal, causing us to be bound and humiliated thus?” The governor kowtowed and begged for mercy. Liu Gen admonished the spirits and dismissed them, and the ordeal ended. A month later, the governor and his wife, Lady Guo, both died.

Chen Chang built houses; Yan Qing pulled boats.
*The Master Who Embraces Simplicity* states: Chen Chang had dwelled on Ramie Mountain for over six hundred years. The mountain folk built him a house and made seasonal offerings. Though he neither ate nor drank, his complexion remained that of a man in his fifties or sixties. Ramie Mountain spanned a thousand *li*, with over a thousand households atop it. Their customs were the same as those of Wu.

Yan Qing was a man of Kuaiji who, though poor, made a living selling charcoal. One day, while on the road, he encountered an extraordinary person who gave him a scroll of plain silk. Yan Qing said, “I cannot read.” The divine being replied, “You need not read it; simply keep it in a quiet place.” Thereafter, Yan Qing gained spiritual powers. When someone pulled his boat, he would disappear, and only the charcoal-laden vessel would move on its own. Later, when he treated the sick, he would bring the scroll to their homes, and they would recover. He entered Mount Xiao Huo and attained immortality.

Xiyi embodied Yao and Shun; Hongya emulated Chao and You.
*The Biographies of Divine Immortals* records: Chen Tuan, styled Tunan and known as Master Xiyi, once encountered a golden-armored divine being who guided him to seclude himself on Mount Hua. Emperor Taizong summoned him and asked, “I wish to govern the realm with the Way of Yao and Shun. Is this possible?” Chen Tuan replied, “I have heard that Yao and Shun had earthen steps three feet high and thatched roofs untrimmed. If Your Majesty can do likewise, then you shall truly be a Yao or Shun of the present age.”

*The Biographies of Eminent Daoists* states: The Daoist Zhang Yun, known as Master Hongya, secluded himself on Mount Yuzhang. During the Kaiyuan era, Emperor Ming summoned him and asked, “How do I compare to Yao and Shun? How do you compare to Xu You?” Zhang Yun replied, “Your Majesty’s Way surpasses that of Yao and Shun, while my virtue falls short of Xu You’s. In ancient times, Yao summoned Xu You, yet Xu You did not come. Today, Your Majesty summoned me, and I have come.” The emperor praised him and offered the title of Master and the rank of Minister of Ceremonies, which he repeatedly declined, eventually rising to Minister of Works. He then said, “Why does Your Majesty begrudge a single mountain and stream, preventing me from following in the footsteps of Chao and You?” The emperor granted his request, and he dwelled on the great cliffs of the Western Mountains, the very place of his former seclusion.

*The Records of Yuzhang* notes: During the Kaihuang era of the Sui, the region was renamed Hongzhou in honor of the mountain where the master resided.
chunks.overlap_context: Records of Emperor Ming* states: When Emperor Ming summoned Zhang Guo, he once offered him wine poured by Dong Yin. Guo drained three goblets in succession, his face flushed with intoxication. Turning to his attendants, he remarked, "This wine is not of fine quality." He then reclined outward, and after the time it takes to eat a meal, he awoke. Suddenly, he gazed into a mirror and saw his teeth mottled and blackened with decay. Seizing an iron *ruyi*, he struck his teeth, and they all fell out.

chunks.original_text: 程戒二虎，陶画两牛。 《高道传》：程太虚，果州西充人，幼好道，年十五登所居之东山，飘然有凌虚意，寻有五色云霞拥其身。 及长，绝粒坐忘，常有二虎随侍出入，师因名之日善言、善行，乃抚其背而授以三归之戒，二虎跪伏以听，自后呼名则至。 《隐居传》：陶隐居先生居积金峰修《真诰》，梁武帝屡诏不起，先生即画两牛以进，一牛散放水草中，一牛着金勒，有人执之，帝曰：先生意效曳尾龟也，不可致之。 许寻偃月，杜拜庭秋。 《列仙传》：许错遍游名山，所至处题字云：寻偃月子到此。 忽作一诗云：闱苑花前是醉乡，误翻王母九霞觞，韦仙拍手嫌轻薄，谪向人问作酒狂。 於酒楼乘云而去。 《高道传》：杜光庭字宾圣，号广成先生。 唐末有狂道士晦名谒先生求寓泊之所，先生虽诺之，未尝与之相见。 道士日货药於市，得钱即沽酒饮之，唯唱感庭秋，时人呼为感庭秋。 几半年，人亦不知其异，一夕大醉，唱声愈高，有窥之者，见灯烛彩绣，筵具器皿罗列甚盛，青童侍立，斟酒而唱。 窥者具以白先生，先生乃款其户曰：光庭量识肤浅，不意上仙降鉴，深为罪戾，愿匍匐一拜光灵，以消尘障。 道士曰：何辱勤拳之若是，当出奉见。 道士即时妆筵具及童子置於冠中，启户空室耳。 方朔窥窗，张平凿井。 《汉武帝故事》：七月七日上御承华殿，有二青鸟来集殿前，上问束方朔，朔曰：西王母欲来。 有顷母至，时南窗下有窥看，帝惊问何人，母曰：是汝侍郎东方朔，性滑稽，我邻家小儿也。 《广记》：唐刺史张士平中年夫妇俱双瞽，遂杜门醮谢，以析保佑，愈久愈勤。 元和问，忽遇一书生曰：此疾不假药饵，但於福地凿并得水洗之可也。 君从之开井，取水洗眼，即时明冷。 夫妇作礼厚谢，书生不受，曰：吾乃太白星官也，以子抱疾不忘於道，精勤无怠，上帝遣我授汝道衍，以答修奉之勤。 金帛之遗，非吾所好。 白至仙居，李践真境。 《广记》：白幽求，贞元中下第，入．海，风飘雨驰，维舟山下，夜闻风击木叶相摩，如人诵诗之声，云玉幢亘碧虚，此乃仙人居之句。 俄而见千余人骑龙控鹤、乘龟履鱼而至，以手指水，如在月中行，有呼水府使者白幽求而授以水府之牒。 幽求随行，忽至一岛上，望见人烟，遂归家，无有存者，云已数代矣。 《仙传拾遗》：李琳，燕人也，宝历中与友人游五台山，偶堕於风．穴中，见一人形如狮子，引入洞中，即以水令琳饮之，且曰：汝虽几流，得入吾洞府，践吾真境，亦有道分矣。 汝有希生之心，今暂归，他日可复来饮此神浆，亦可延年益寿矣。 昭王怀珠，玄帝埋鼎。 《仙传拾遗》：昔黄帝时务成子游寒山之岭，见黑蚌在高崖之上，故知黑蚌能飞矣。 至燕昭王时，其国献於昭王，昭王取珪璋之水洗其沙泥，乃叹曰：自有日月以来，见黑蚌生珠已八九十遇，此蚌千岁一珠也。 王暑月常怀此珠，体自轻冻，号销暑招凉珠。 《真诰》：大茅山有玄帝时铜鼎，鼎可容四五斛，在山独高处，入土八尺许，上有盘石掩鼎上，玄帝时命东海神使埋藏於此。 武丁被召，少君言请。 《仙传拾遗》：成武丁，桂阳人也，年十三为县宰遣送物上州，州牧周听异之，留为文学主薄。

Programming two tigers, painting two oxen.

*The Biographies of Eminent Daoists* records: Cheng Taixu, a native of Xichong in Guozhou, was drawn to the Dao from childhood. At fifteen, he ascended the eastern mountain near his home, where a lofty aspiration to transcend the mundane arose within him. Soon after, clouds of five colors enveloped his body. In adulthood, he ceased grain and sat in forgetfulness. Two tigers would accompany him wherever he went. He named them Good Speech and Good Conduct, then stroked their backs and administered the Three Refuges. The tigers knelt and listened attentively. Thereafter, they would come whenever he called their names.

*The Biographies of Recluses* states: Master Tao the Recluse dwelled on Mount Jijin, compiling the *True Instructions*. Though Emperor Wu of Liang repeatedly summoned him, he never responded. Instead, the master painted two oxen and presented them to the emperor—one roaming freely amidst water and grass, the other fitted with a golden bridle and held by a man. The emperor remarked, “The master’s intent is like the tortoise dragging its tail in the mud. He cannot be compelled.” Thus, he ceased his summons.

Xu sought the crescent moon, Du bowed to the autumn courtyard.

*The Biographies of Immortals* recounts: Xu Cuo wandered through famous mountains, leaving inscriptions wherever he went: “Here passes the Seeker of the Crescent Moon.” One day, he composed a poem:
*“Before the flowers of the celestial garden lies the land of drunkenness,
Mistakenly I drained the Queen Mother’s ninefold rosy goblet.
Venerable Wei clapped his hands, deeming me frivolous,
And banished me to the mortal world as a wine-mad fool.”*
Thereupon, he ascended upon clouds from a tavern.

*The Biographies of Eminent Daoists* records: Du Guangting, styled Binsheng, was also known as Master Guangcheng. At the end of the Tang, a reclusive Daoist whose name was obscure sought lodging with him. Though the master assented, he never granted the man an audience. The Daoist sold medicines in the market by day, spending his earnings on wine, and would sing only *“Lamenting the Autumn Courtyard.”* The people called him the *“Autumn Courtyard Lamenter.”* For nearly half a year, none suspected his strangeness. One evening, deeply intoxicated, his singing grew louder. Those who peered in saw lamps and embroidered banners, tables laden with vessels, and azure youths standing by to pour wine as he sang. The onlookers reported this to the master, who then knocked at his door, saying, *“Guangting’s capacity and knowledge are shallow. I never imagined a transcendent would deign to visit. I am deeply at fault. I humbly beg to bow before your radiant presence, that my worldly obstructions may be dispelled.”* The Daoist replied, *“Why such earnestness? I shall come out to meet you.”* In an instant, he stowed the banquet and attendants into his cap, opened the door—and the room was empty.

Dongfang Peeped at the Window, Zhang Ping Dug a Well.

*The Tales of Emperor Wu of Han* states: On the seventh day of the seventh month, the emperor was in the Cheng Hua Hall when two azure birds alighted before it. The emperor asked Dongfang Shuo, who replied, *“The Queen Mother of the West is about to arrive.”* Soon after, she appeared. Someone was peering through the southern window. The emperor, startled, asked who it was. The Queen Mother said, *“That is your attendant, Dongfang Shuo. He is a witty fellow—just a mischievous boy from my neighborhood.”*

*The Extensive Records* recounts: During the Yuanhe era, Prefect Zhang Shiping of the Tang and his wife both went blind in middle age. They shut their doors, performing rituals and prayers without cease, their devotion growing ever more fervent. One day, a scholar appeared and said, *“This affliction requires no medicine. Simply dig a well in a blessed site and wash your eyes with its water.”* The prefect followed his advice. The moment he washed his eyes, his vision cleared. The couple bowed in gratitude and offered rich gifts, but the scholar refused, saying, *“I am an official of the Star of Venus. Because you have endured illness without forsaking the Dao, your devotion unwavering, the Celestial Emperor sent me to impart the Dao’s mysteries in repayment for your diligence. Gold and silk are not what I seek.”*

Bai Reached the Immortals’ Abode, Li Trod the True Realm.

*The Extensive Records* states: Bai Youqiu failed the imperial examinations during the Zhenyuan era. He sailed into the sea, where wind and rain drove his boat to the foot of a mountain. That night, he heard the wind rustling the leaves like the sound of someone reciting poetry:
*“A jade canopy spans the azure void—
This is the dwelling of immortals.”*
Suddenly, over a thousand riders appeared, mounted on dragons, cranes, turtles, and fish. They pointed to the water, which seemed to flow beneath the moon. Someone called out, *“Water Bureau Messenger Bai Youqiu!”* and handed him a document from the Water Bureau. Youqiu followed them and soon reached an island. Gazing into the distance, he saw signs of human habitation. When he returned home, none of his family remained—generations had passed.

*The Supplement to the Biographies of Immortals* records: Li Lin, a native of Yan, was traveling with a friend on Mount Wutai during the Baoli era when he fell into a wind cave. A lion-like figure led him into a cavern and gave him water to drink, saying, *“Though you nearly perished, you have entered my grotto and trodden my true realm—this is your destined affinity with the Dao. If you harbor the desire for long life, return home for now. You may come again to drink this divine nectar, which will extend your years.”*

King Zhao Treasured the Pearl, the Dark Emperor Buried the Cauldron.

*The Supplement to the Biographies of Immortals* states: In the time of the Yellow Emperor, Wuchengzi wandered the ridges of Mount Hanshan when he saw a black clam on a high cliff, proving that black clams could fly. By the era of King Zhao of Yan, the kingdom presented one to the king. He washed its sand and mud with water from a jade vessel, then sighed, *“Since the dawn of sun and moon, I have seen black clams produce pearls eighty or ninety times—but this clam yields a pearl only once in a thousand years.”* The king carried this pearl in his bosom during the summer, and his body felt light and cool. It was called the *“Heat-Dispelling, Coolness-Summoning Pearl.”*

*The True Instructions* records: On Great Mount Mao stands a bronze cauldron from the time of the Dark Emperor, large enough to hold four or five *hu*. It rests on the mountain’s highest point, buried eight *chi* deep, with a slab of stone covering it. The Dark Emperor ordered the Spirit of the Eastern Sea to conceal it there.

Wu Ding Was Summoned, Master Shao Requested Audience.

*The Supplement to the Biographies of Immortals* states: Cheng Wuding, a native of Guiyang, became a county magistrate at thirteen and was sent to deliver goods to the provincial capital. The governor, Zhou Ting, recognized his exceptional qualities and retained him as a literary aide.

chunks.original_text: 因被使自京还过长沙郡，投邮合不及，遂宿野木下，忽闻人有语云：向长沙市药。 平旦见二鹤，君异之，遂往市门伺侯，果见二老人，君从之数里，老人问：子随我何求耶。 曰：闻有济生之衍，因来侍从耳。 老人顾笑，於袖中出玉函，看素书，果有武丁姓名，各出药一粒与之，因而得道。 一日谓弟曰：七月七日牵牛诣织女，吾被召还官，不得久留。 言讫而卒，后葬，太守，使人发棺，不复见尸，但有青竹杖并乌而已。 《神仙传》：李少君尝合丹，丹未成，谓武帝曰：陛下不能绝奢侈，远声色，杀伐不止，喜怒不除，万里有不归之魂，市朝有流血之鬼，神丹大道未可得成也。 少君忽称病，是夕帝梦与少君俱上嵩山，半道有使者乘龙持节从云中下，言太一请少君，帝觉，谓近臣曰：少君将舍我去。 明日少君疾困，帝自往视，则已化矣，帝曰：故化去耳。 敛而失之。 三洞群仙录卷之七竟 三洞群仙录卷之八

Upon his return from the capital, he passed through Changsha Prefecture. As he missed the postal relay’s closing hour, he lodged beneath a tree in the wild. Suddenly, he heard voices saying, “We’re heading to Changsha’s market for medicine.” At dawn, he saw two cranes. Finding this strange, he followed them to the market gate and waited. Sure enough, two elderly men appeared. He trailed them for several *li* before one asked, “What do you seek by following us?” He replied, “I heard of your life-saving arts and came to serve as your attendant.” The elders exchanged glances and smiled, then drew a jade case from their sleeves. Upon examining a plain silk scroll, they found Cheng Wuding’s name inscribed. Each gave him a single pill, and by this he attained the Dao.

One day, he told his younger brother, “On the seventh day of the seventh month, the Herdboy visits the Weaver Girl. I have been summoned back to my post and cannot stay long.” With these words, he passed away. After his burial, the prefect ordered the coffin opened, but his body was gone—only a green bamboo staff and a black crow remained.

*The Traditions of Divine Transcendents* records: Li Shaojun once compounded an elixir, but before its completion, he told Emperor Wu, “Your Majesty cannot forsake extravagance, distance yourself from sensual pleasures, cease warfare, or temper your wrath. Lost souls wander beyond the ten thousand *li*, and ghosts of the slain haunt the marketplace. The great elixir and the supreme Dao cannot be achieved under such conditions.” Suddenly, Shaojun fell ill. That night, the emperor dreamed they ascended Mount Song together when a messenger riding a dragon descended from the clouds, bearing a tally, and announced, “The Great One summons Shaojun.” The emperor awoke and told his attendants, “Shaojun will soon leave me.” The next day, Shaojun’s condition worsened. The emperor visited him personally, only to find he had already transformed. The emperor said, “He has merely departed in this manner.” When they prepared to encoffin him, his body had vanished.

chunks.original_text: 正一道士陈葆光撰集 漆园傲吏，烟波钓徒。 晋郭璞游仙诗曰：漆园有傲史，莱氏有逸妻。 注云：庄子尝为漆园史，楚威王使厚币迎，许以为相，庄周笑谓楚使曰：亟去，无污我漆园傲史。 《渔歌记》：宪．宗求访玄真子《渔歌》，李德裕为润州刺史，乃获之。 玄真子，张志和也，自号烟波钓徒，歌曰：西塞山边白乌飞，桃花流水鳜鱼肥，青着笠，绿蓑衣，斜风细雨不须归。 二曰：钓渔父，褐为裘，两两三三舫艋舟。 能纵棹，惯乘流，长江白浪不曾忧。 三曰：霄汉湾裹钓鱼仓，舫艋为家西复东，江上雪，浦边风，笑着荷衣不叹穷。 四曰：松江蟹舍主人欢，菰饭尊羹亦共准，枫叶落，荻花乾，醉拍渔舟不觉寒。 五曰：青草湖中月正圆，巴陵渔父棹歌莲，钓车子，獗头船，乐在风波不用仙。 苏耽鹤柜，孙真牛车。 《梆江集》：苏仙君耽忽一日扫洒庭宇，具衣冠，若有所待。 俄见西北云鹤翔集，从空而下，君乃入，跪白母曰：太上召补为真官，仪卫已至，不得终养。 言讫拜辞，子母戏歌久之，母曰：汝去后，使我何以存养。 君因留一柜，肩镍甚固，曰：有所阙乏，可扣柜呼之，所须即至，慎勿开也。 自后母但有所阙，叩柜其物立至。 母一日心疑其柜，开视之有双鹤飞去，自后虽扣，无复应矣。 《抱朴子》：孙真事帛和先生得其道，一日告行，先生将一符函与之，云：前有牛车迎汝即乘之，所有供给行厨，食之无疑，切不可开函。 真跪受，以行前果有牛车来，问曰：君是孙道士乎，帛君遣制相迎。 真上车如飞，每渡水不由桥梁，酒食供给悉备。 一日弟子窃开，只见画牛车一乘，即时不知所在。 真后亦数与帛和乘车出入。 弥明赋鼎，陶白携壶。 《高道传》：道士轩辕弥明往来衡、湘问，与刘师服友善。 弥明自衡山过太白，知师服在京，夜抵其居。 校书郎侯喜有诗名，与师服拥炉说诗，弥明在座，貌甚陋，喜视之蔑如也，弥明因指炉中石鼎曰：二子能赋此乎。 师服虽旧识，不知其有文也，刘先生吟曰：巧匠新山骨，制中事煎烹。 次侯曰：直柄未当权，塞届且吞声。 弥明哑然笑曰：子诗如是而已。 因高吟迭赋十余韵，弥明应之如响，二子思竭不能续，起谢曰：尊师非世人能出也。 其辈伏矣。 《广记》：陶太白公每以探药为业，一日携壶拉友游嵩山，坐於林下，闻松梢有笑语之声，仰视果有二人，公曰：君铃神仙，可能下降而共饮乎。 俄见一丈夫、女子，古服而下曰：予乃秦之役夫也，毛女乃秦之官人，与予同脱骊山之祸，乃匿於此。 陶曰：今遇真仙，金丹大药可得闻乎。 曰：予本几人，但能绝世食木实，乃得凌虚，不觉生之与死、俗之与仙如何耳。 遂折松枝叩壶而歌曰：饵柏身轻迭蟑间，是非无意到人寰。 冠裳暂备论浮世，一饷云游碧落问。 子良青简，永叔丹书。

Chen Baoguang of the Orthodox Unity Dao, compiler.

The Proud Clerk of Qiyuan, the Fisherman of Misty Waves.
Jin poet Guo Pu’s *Wandering Immortal Poems* states: “Qiyuan has its proud clerk, Lai has its reclusive wife.” The annotation explains: Zhuangzi once served as clerk of Qiyuan. King Wei of Chu sent generous gifts to summon him, offering the position of minister. Zhuang Zhou laughed and said to the envoy, “Begone! Do not defile me, the proud clerk of Qiyuan.”

*The Fisherman’s Songs Record* recounts: Emperor Xianzong sought the *Fisherman’s Songs* of Master Xuan Zhen. Li Deyu, then prefect of Runzhou, obtained them. Master Xuan Zhen was Zhang Zhihé, who styled himself the Fisherman of Misty Waves. His song reads:
*By West Ford Mountain, white gulls take flight,*
*Peach blossoms drift on waters where mandarin fish grow plump.*
*In blue hat and green raincoat,*
*Through slanting wind and fine rain, no need to return.*

Second song:
*The fisherman’s father, clad in coarse brown,*
*Pairs or trios in skiffs light as water striders.*
*Skilled at sculling, accustomed to riding the current,*
*On the Yangtze’s white waves, never a care.*

Third song:
*In the bend of the Milky Way, fishing from a granary boat,*
*Skiffs as homes, drifting west and east.*
*Snow on the river, wind on the shore,*
*Laughing in lotus robes, never sighing at poverty.*

Fourth song:
*At the crab shack by Song River, the host is full of cheer,*
*Wild rice for rice, water-plant soup—all shared alike.*
*Maple leaves fall, reeds wither dry,*
*Drunk, he slaps the fishing boat, unaware of the cold.*

Fifth song:
*On Green Grass Lake, the moon is full and round,*
*At Baling, the fisherman’s oar sings of lotuses.*
*With a fishing reel and a flat-headed boat,*
*Joy lies in wind and waves—no need for transcendence.*

Su Dan’s Crane Cabinet, Sun Zhen’s Oxcart.
*The Bangjiang Collection* records: Lord Su Dan of Su County one day swept and tidied his courtyard, donned his robes and cap, as if awaiting someone. Suddenly, from the northwest, clouds and cranes gathered and descended from the sky. He entered, knelt, and told his mother, “The Supreme One summons me to fill a post as a perfected official. The ceremonial escort has arrived; I cannot remain to care for you.” Having spoken, he bowed in farewell. Mother and son sang playfully for a long time. His mother said, “After you leave, how shall I sustain myself?” He left behind a cabinet, its lock and hinges exceptionally sturdy, saying, “When you lack anything, knock on the cabinet and call for it—what you need will arrive at once. But never open it.” Thereafter, whenever his mother lacked something, she knocked on the cabinet, and the object would appear immediately. One day, his mother grew curious and opened the cabinet. A pair of cranes flew out, and though she knocked afterward, there was no response.

*The Master Who Embraces Simplicity* states: Sun Zhen studied the Dao under Master Bo He and attained it. One day, he announced his departure. The master gave him a sealed talisman box, saying, “Ahead, an oxcart will come to welcome you—board it. All provisions and traveling kitchens will be provided; eat without doubt. But under no circumstances open the box.” Sun Zhen knelt and received it. As he set out, an oxcart indeed arrived. The driver asked, “Are you Daoist Sun? Master Bo has sent me to welcome you.” Sun Zhen boarded, and the cart flew like the wind. Whenever they crossed water, they did not use bridges. Wine and food were fully supplied. One day, his disciple secretly opened the box and saw only a painted oxcart. Immediately, Sun Zhen vanished without a trace. Later, he was seen several times riding out and about with Bo He.

Mi Ming’s Cauldron Rhapsody, Tao Bai’s Gourd.
*The Biographies of Eminent Daoists* records: Daoist Xuan Yuan Mi Ming traveled between Heng and Xiang, befriending Liu Shifu. Mi Ming, passing through Mount Tai Bai, learned Shifu was in the capital and arrived at his residence that night. The collator Hou Xi was renowned for his poetry and was discussing verses with Shifu by the brazier. Mi Ming sat among them, his appearance exceedingly plain. Hou Xi looked at him with disdain. Mi Ming pointed to the stone cauldron in the brazier and said, “Can the two of you rhapsodize on this?” Though Shifu had known him for some time, he did not realize Mi Ming was a man of letters. Master Liu recited:
*A skillful craftsman carves new mountain bones,*
*Shaping within the affairs of boiling and brewing.*

Next, Hou Xi said:
*The straight handle does not grasp authority,*
*Blocked and constrained, it can only swallow its voice.*

Mi Ming laughed soundlessly and said, “Is this the extent of your poetry?” Then he chanted in a loud voice, composing over ten verses in succession. Mi Ming responded as if echoing, while the two men exhausted their thoughts but could not continue. They rose and bowed, saying, “Venerable master, none in this world can surpass you.” Their peers were humbled.

*The Extensive Records* states: Lord Tao Tai Bai often made gathering herbs his vocation. One day, he carried a gourd and invited a friend to wander Mount Song. Sitting beneath the trees, they heard laughter and conversation from the pine branches above. Looking up, they saw two figures. Lord Tao said, “You must be divine immortals—might you descend and drink with us?” Soon, a man and a woman in ancient attire descended, saying, “I was a laborer of Qin, and Mao Nü was a palace woman of Qin. Together, we escaped the disaster of Mount Li and have hidden here.” Tao said, “Now that we have met true immortals, may we hear of the great elixir and golden medicine?” They replied, “We are but ordinary people. By cutting ourselves off from the world and eating pine nuts, we came to soar through the void, unaware of the difference between life and death, the mundane and the transcendent.” Then they broke a pine branch, tapped the gourd, and sang:
*Feeding on cypress, the body grows light, leaping among cicadas,*
*Right and wrong hold no meaning when one reaches the human realm.*
*Caps and robes briefly adorn the floating world,*
*For a moment, cloud-wandering through the azure heavens.*

chunks.original_text: 《真诰》：周子良，陶隐居之弟子，自幼温雅，肃然高迈。 天监中，真仙屡降其室曰：周生修功积德，可为不负其志矣。 子良曰：枉蒙上真赐降，欣惧交心，无以自措。 司命君曰：近往束华，见子之名已上青简保列保晨司矣。 《青琐》：欧阳永叔与梅圣俞游嵩山，醉望西峰崖上有丹书四大字云神清之洞，永叔指示圣俞问无所见，公乃不言。 洎乞身告世，作诗曰：四字丹书万仞崖，神清之洞镍楼台。 烟霞极目无人到，鸾鹤今应待我来。 后数日公薨。 元化湔肠，黄眉洗髓。

*The True Records* states: Zhou Ziliang, disciple of Tao the Recluse, was refined and solemn from youth, lofty in bearing. During the Tianjian era, true immortals descended repeatedly to his chamber, saying, “Zhou has cultivated merit and accumulated virtue—he has not betrayed his aspirations.” Ziliang replied, “I am unworthy of the High Perfected’s descent; joy and awe mingle in my heart, leaving me at a loss.” The Lord of Life and Destiny said, “Recently, I journeyed to the Eastern Flower Capital and saw your name already inscribed on the Azure Slips, recorded in the registers of the Dawn Bureau.”

*The Green Jade Pendant* records: Ouyang Yongshu and Mei Shengyu roamed Mount Song. Drunk, they gazed toward the western peak, where four great cinnabar characters on the cliff read *Grotto of Divine Clarity*. Yongshu pointed them out to Shengyu, who saw nothing. Yongshu fell silent. Later, when he petitioned to withdraw from the world, he composed a poem:
*Four cinnabar characters on a cliff ten thousand fathoms high,*
*The Grotto of Divine Clarity, its towers wrought in jade.*
*Gazing through mist and clouds, none reach that distant place—*
*Phoenix and crane must now await my coming.*

A few days later, he passed away.

chunks.original_text: 《后汉》：华陀字元化，仙人也。 沛相陈珪举孝康，太尉黄瑰辟，皆不就。 精於方药，处剂不过数种。 若疾发结於内，针药所不能及者，乃先令以酒服麻沸散，既醉无所觉，因制破肠背，抽割积聚。 若在肠胃，则断截湔洗，除去疾秽，既而缝合，傅以神膏，四五日则愈，一月之问皆平复。 《汉武故事》：东方朔生三日而父母俱亡、或得之而不知其姓，以见时东方始明，因以为姓。 既长，常空中独语。 后游鸿蒙之泽，有老母探桑，自言朔母，一黄眉肴至，指朔曰：此吾兄也，吾却食服气三千年一反骨洗髓，二千年一剥皮伐毛，吾生已三洗髓、五伐毛矣。 郝姑挑蔬，许仆市米。 《女仙传》：郝姑祠在莫州莫县西北，俗传云：郝姑者字女君，魏青龙中与邻女於愍演水边挑蔬，忽二青童至前曰：东海公娶女君为妇。 言讫，敷连捆褥於水上，行坐往来，有若陆地。 童子侍侧，泌流而下。

*The Later Han Records* state: Hua Tuo, styled Yuanhua, was an immortal. Magistrate Chen Gui of Pei recommended him for filial piety and incorruptibility, and Grand Commandant Huang Gai summoned him to office, but he declined all appointments. Proficient in prescriptions and remedies, his formulas never exceeded a few ingredients. When illness arose deep within the body, beyond the reach of acupuncture or medicine, he would first administer a dose of *mafei* powder dissolved in wine. Once the patient was insensate with drunkenness, he would incise the abdomen or back to excise accumulations. If the affliction lay in the intestines or stomach, he would sever, rinse, and cleanse them, removing the diseased filth before suturing the wound and applying a divine ointment. Recovery came in four or five days, with full restoration within a month.

*The Tales of Emperor Wu of Han* recount: Dongfang Shuo lost both parents three days after his birth. Someone found him but knew not his surname, so—observing that dawn first brightened in the east—named him thus. As he grew, he often spoke to himself in empty air. Later, while wandering the Vast Obscurity Marsh, an old woman gathering mulberry leaves claimed to be his mother. A yellow-browed elder arrived and pointed at Shuo, saying, “This is my elder brother. I abstain from grain and ingest *qi*, returning every three thousand years to wash my marrow and every two thousand years to flay my skin and shed my hair. In my life, I have already washed my marrow thrice and flayed my skin five times.” Hao Gu picks vegetables; Xu Pu buys rice.

*The Biographies of Female Immortals* state: The shrine of Hao Gu stands northwest of Mo County in Mo Prefecture. Popular tradition holds that Hao Gu, styled Nüjun, was gathering vegetables by the Minyan River with a neighbor during the Qinglong era of the Wei dynasty when two azure lads appeared before them, saying, “The Duke of the Eastern Sea seeks Nüjun as his bride.” With these words, they spread a brocade mat upon the water, where it moved as if on solid ground. The lads attended her as the current carried them downstream.

The neighbor girl ran to inform her family, who rushed to the scene but could find nothing. From afar, Nüjun called out: “By the grace of the Water Immortals, I pray you do not grieve or fear.” Later, a shrine was erected by the water’s edge, and before it suddenly appeared two stones—one vertical, one horizontal—each about three feet wide and over two feet high. *The Imperial Anthology of Categories* states: On West Mountain in Hongzhou lived a couple, Master and Madam Xu, who wandered in and out of the mountains. Tradition holds they were the servants of Xu Jingyang. Once, while purchasing rice with his wife at West Ridge, they returned to find their master’s entire household had ascended to immortality. Master Xu left a poem:

*Since the Prefect departed for the immortals,*
*I’ve wandered the mortal world to this very day.*
*Not to deceive the world by blending with俗,*
*But to sell firewood and buy wine, to settle the heart.*

Xu Jingyang had conferred upon them the arts of earthbound immortality, changing their surname to *Gan Da*. To this day, many claim to have seen them.

*Playful ministers drum their lips; mad scholars cover their ears.*

*Miscellaneous Morsels from Youyang* records: Xing Hepu once hosted a guest who, laughing uproariously with his beard bristling and lips stretching to his ears, engaged Xing in spirited conversation before departing. When asked about it, he replied: “The Celestial Emperor was toying with his minister.”

*The Biographies of Divine Immortals* states: Outside the southern gate of Hezhou, a ragged madman was seen selling bottle gourd seeds, claiming: “In a year or two, these will prove most useful.” Yet no one understood their purpose. At times, he would clap his hands over his ears and dash away, muttering: “Why is the sound of wind and water so deafening?”

Popular tradition holds that Hao Gu, styled Nüjun, was gathering vegetables by the Minyan River with a neighbor during the Qinglong era of the Wei dynasty when two azure lads appeared before them, saying, “The Duke of the Eastern Sea seeks Nüjun as his bride.” With these words, they spread a brocade mat upon the water, where it moved as if on solid ground. chunks.original_text: 孩童随之，时人呼为掩耳先生。 来年秋，江水涨泛，淹没数百家，众人皆见狂士在水上坐一大瓢，两手掩耳，大呼风水声何太甚，泛江而去。 北海挂冠，南阳遗履。 《后汉逸史》：逢前字子康，北海都昌人也。 家贫给事县为亭长，时尉行过亭，萌侯迎拜谒，既而掷循叹曰：大丈夫安能为人役哉。 即解冠挂东都城门，归将家属浮海，客於辽东，后之琅琊劳山，养志修道，人皆化其德。 《集仙传》：汉南阳公主出降王咸。 属王莽秉政，公主夙慕清虚，尚崇至道，每追文、景之为理，又知武帝之世累降神仙，谓咸曰：国祚如此，非女子可以扶持，但当自保恬和，退身修道，稍远骂竞，铃可延生。 若碌碌随时，恐不可免於支离之息。 遂入华山，结庐精思，真灵屡降，道成乘云飞升而去，但於岭上遗朱履一双，前取之，已化为石，因谓之公主峰。 王卿白兔，吕公青蛇。 《原化记》：王卿为天师守丹电，窃发其封而窥一白兔跃出，众皆曰：丹已去矣。 一道士化为鹤飞去，须突擒兔来复投莆中。 《青琐》：贾师雄郎中有古铁镒，甚宝之，久欲淬磨，有回处士言善磨镒，笋中取药堆鉴上、曰：药少顷归取之。 既去，久不至，遣人询其宿止，乃在寺中，题诗寺门上：手内青蛇凌白日，洞中仙果艳长春。 须知物外烟霞客，不是尘中磨镜人。 公视镒上，药已飞去，一点表裹光明。 又赠张洎云：朝游南越暮苍梧，袖裹青蛇胆气粗。 三入岳阳人不识，高吟飞过洞庭湖。 钱真飞练，女褒洗纱。 《茅山记》：女真钱氏二姊妹依止茅山隐陶居诵《黄庭经》，积三十年，一日告别，先生曰：何之。 答曰：上宾金阙。 先生以诗赠之云：道士送仙客，送到大茅束。 太华十万里，远望杳冥鸿。 真人答诗曰：师住好师住，劳师远相送。 仙籍有仙名，名在蓬莱洞。 即时飞练入洞，及女弟至，则洞已肩矣，即今燕洞是也，有紫莒蒲、碧桃焉，故田霖有诗云：燕洞龙泓气象清，钱真此处有遗灵。 仙兄去后师犹在，女弟回时洞已肩。 云片尚如披白练，泉声长似说《黄庭》。 碧桃花发莒薄紫，留与人间作画屏。
chunks.translated_text:
The children followed him, and the people of the time called him "Master Cover-Ears." The following autumn, the Yangtze River swelled and flooded, submerging hundreds of households. Many witnessed the madman sitting atop a large gourd on the water, hands pressed over his ears, crying out, *"Why is the sound of wind and water so deafening?"* before drifting away on the river.

*Crown hung at Beihai, shoes left at Nanyang.*

*The Unofficial History of the Later Han* records: Feng Qian, styled Zikang, was a native of Duchang in Beihai. Impoverished, he served as a pavilion chief in the county. When the magistrate passed by his post, Feng greeted him with bows. Soon after, he cast aside his official tablet and sighed, *"How can a true man be another’s servant?"* He immediately removed his cap and hung it on the gate of the Eastern Capital, then returned home to take his family across the sea. They settled as guests in Liaodong before journeying to Mount Lao in Langye, where he cultivated his will and refined the Dao. The people were all transformed by his virtue.

*The Collected Biographies of Immortals* states: Princess Nanyang of the Han married Wang Xian. When Wang Mang usurped power, the princess, long admiring purity and revering the supreme Dao, often reflected on the governance of Emperors Wen and Jing. Knowing that immortals had descended multiple times during Emperor Wu’s reign, she told Wang Xian: *"With the fate of the nation thus, it is not for a woman to prop it up. One should preserve tranquility, withdraw to cultivate the Dao, and distance oneself from strife to prolong life. If one blindly follows the times, I fear one cannot escape the breath of decay."* She then entered Mount Hua, built a hut, and devoted herself to meditation. True spirits descended frequently, and upon achieving the Dao, she ascended on clouds. Only a pair of red shoes remained on the peak, which turned to stone when retrieved. Thus, the place was named Princess Peak.

*Minister Wang’s white hare, Master Lü’s green snake.*

*The Records of Origins and Transformations* recounts: Minister Wang guarded the alchemical crucible for the Celestial Master. When he secretly broke the seal and peeked inside, a white hare leapt out. The crowd exclaimed, *"The elixir is gone!"* A Daoist transformed into a crane and flew away, but in an instant, he seized the hare and returned it to the crucible.

*The Green Pivot* records: Langzhong Jia Shixiong treasured an ancient iron mirror and long wished to polish it. A recluse named Hui claimed skill in mirror-polishing. Taking medicine from his bamboo tube, he piled it on the mirror and said, *"The medicine will be ready shortly—I will return for it."* After he left and did not return for a long time, Jia sent someone to inquire about his lodging. He was found in a temple, where he had inscribed a poem on the gate:
*"In hand, a green snake soars beneath the white sun;
In the cave, immortal fruits bloom with eternal spring.
Know this: the mist-and-clouds wanderer beyond the world
Is no mere mortal who polishes mirrors in the dust."*

When Jia examined the mirror, the medicine had vanished, leaving only a single luminous speck. The recluse also gifted a poem to Zhang Ji:
*"At dawn I roam Nanyue, by dusk I reach Cangwu;
In my sleeve, a green snake—my gall bold and fierce.
Thrice I entered Yueyang, yet none recognized me;
Chanting high, I soared past Dongting Lake."*

*Qian the True’s flying silk, Lady Bao’s washing gauze.*

*The Records of Mount Mao* tell of two sisters of the Qian family, female immortals who dwelled in seclusion on Mount Mao, reciting the *Scripture of the Yellow Court* for thirty years. One day, they bid farewell to their master, who asked, *"Where are you going?"* They replied, *"To the golden gates of the celestial palace."* The master composed a poem to send them off:
*"A Daoist sees off immortal guests,
Escorting them to the eastern peak of Great Mao.
A hundred thousand li to Mount Taihua—
Gazing afar at the dim and distant swan."*

The True Ones answered with a poem:
*"Stay well, Master, stay well;
Do not trouble yourself with this distant farewell.
The immortal roster bears our names—
Our names are recorded in Penglai’s grotto."*

At that moment, they ascended into the cave on flying silk. When the younger sister arrived, the cave had already sealed itself. This is the present-day Swallow Cave, where purple calamus and jade peach trees grow. Thus, Tian Lin wrote:
*"Swallow Cave and Dragon Spring, their aura pure and bright;
Here, the True Qian left her lingering spirit.
Though the elder sister departed, the master remained;
When the younger returned, the cave had sealed tight.
Clouds still unfurl like white silk,
The spring’s voice forever recites the* Yellow Court.
*Jade peaches bloom, calamus turns purple—
Left for the mortal world as a painted screen."*

chunks.original_text: 《仙传拾遗》：褒女者，汉中人也，居泸、沔二水之闲，幼慕冲寂，既升，因洗纱於水际，云雨晦冥，若有所感而孕。 父母责之，忧患而疾，临终谓其母曰：死后当以牛车载送西山之上，即所愿也。 言讫而终。 父母置之於车中，未及驾牛，而车自行，瑜汉、烬二水横流而渡，直上平原山岭。 家人追之，但见五云如盖，天乐震空，幢节导从其女升天，视车中，空棺而已。 张白饮酒，樵青煎茶。 《括异志》：张白字虚白，自称白云子，好沉静，博学能文，两举不第，每沉湎於酒，会亲丧，乃泣曰：禄以养亲，今亲不逮，干禄何为。 遂辟谷养气全神为事，因脱去儒服为道士。 入郾中，多行诟马，切中人微隐之事。 风雪苦寒叉破冰深入水中安坐，气如蒸炊，指顾之问，悉以乾燥。 居常饮崔氏酒肆，尝题其壁云：武陵溪畔崔家酒，地上应无天上有，南来道士饮一斗，醉外白云深洞口。 其后解去。 《腔说》：张志和有奴日渔童，婢日樵青，或问其故，曰：奴使捧钓取纶，芦中鼓松，婢使樵兰薪桂，竹裹煎茶。
chunks.translated_text:
*The Supplementary Records of Immortals’ Biographies* states: The Lady of Bao was a native of Hanzhong, dwelling between the Lu and Mian rivers. From childhood, she yearned for emptiness and stillness. Once, while washing silk by the water’s edge, clouds and rain darkened the sky, and she conceived as if moved by some unseen force. Her parents reproached her, and in her distress, she fell ill. On her deathbed, she told her mother: “After I die, place me in an ox-cart and send me to the western mountains—this is my wish.” With these words, she passed away.

Her parents laid her in the cart, but before the oxen could be harnessed, the cart moved of its own accord. It crossed the Han and Jin rivers, which surged and flowed sideways to let it pass, ascending directly to the plains and ridges of the mountains. When her family pursued her, they saw only five clouds like a canopy, celestial music resounding through the sky, and banners and standards leading the lady as she ascended to heaven. Looking into the cart, they found only an empty coffin.

Zhang Bai drank wine, while Qiao Qing brewed tea.

*The Comprehensive Record of Marvels* states: Zhang Bai, styled Xubai, called himself the Master of White Clouds. Fond of solitude and tranquility, he was learned and well-versed in literature. Though he sat for the imperial examinations twice, he never passed. He often drowned his sorrows in wine, but after his parents’ deaths, he wept and said: “Office is for nourishing one’s parents—now that they are gone, why seek rank?” He then abandoned grain, cultivating qi and preserving his spirit, and cast off his scholar’s robes to become a Daoist.

In Yanzhong, he often rode a scolding horse, his words piercing the hidden faults of others. In bitter wind and snow, he would break the ice, sit deep in the water, and emerge with steam rising from his body, his clothes dry in an instant. He frequented the Cui family’s tavern, where he once inscribed on the wall:
*“At the Cui family’s tavern by Wuling Stream,
Such wine exists not on earth but only in heaven.
A southern Daoist drinks a dou—
Beyond drunkenness, white clouds fill the deep cave’s mouth.”*
Later, the inscription vanished.

*The Empty Sayings* states: Zhang Zhihe had a servant named Fisher Lad and a maid named Woodcutter Green. When asked the reason, he replied: “My servant tends the fishing line and plucks the zither among the reeds; my maid gathers orchid firewood and cassia kindling, brewing tea in bamboo.”

chunks.original_text: 王老打麦，张泊破瓜。 《神仙传》：王老，房州宜君县人也，居於村野，颇好道爱客。 一旦有缢缕道士造门，王老与妻延礼之，居月余，道士俄遍身恶疮，王老为求医看疗益勤，道士言不烦以几药，但得美酒数斛，浸之自愈。 王老乃为造酒，及熟，道士命贮以大瓮，自加药浸之，遂入瓮，二日方出，须鬓俱黑，颜复少年，肌若凝脂焉。 仍令王老饮之，王老时方打麦，与其妻子并打麦人共饮，皆大醉，道士亦饮，云：可上天去否。 於是祥风忽起，彩云如蒸，全家人物鸡犬一时飞去，空中犹闻打麦之声。 今宜君县西有升仙村存焉。 《杨文公谈苑》：张洎家居城外，有一隐士乃吕仙翁姓名，洎倒展见之，索纸笔，八分书七言诗一章留与洎，颇言将相鼎鼎之意，其未句云：功成当在破瓜年。 俗以破瓜字为二八，洎果得六十八，乃其识也。 巫山云雨，姑射冰雪。 《集仙录》：云华夫人，王母第二十三女，名瑶姬，尝游束海，还过江上，有巫山焉，峰昆挺技，林壑幽丽，巨石如坛，留连久之。 时大禹理水驻於山下，大风卒至，崖谷振陨，力不可制，因与瑶姬相值，拜而求助，即敕侍女授禹策召鬼神，因命其神助禹斩石疏波，次塞道阮，以存其流。 禹尝诣之於崇嗽，顾陌之际化而为石，或倏然飞腾，散为轻云，或悠然而止，聚为夕雨，或为飞龙，或为翔鹤，千态万状，不可亲也。 其后楚大夫宋玉以其事言於襄王，王不能访其道要以求长生，筑台於高唐之馆，作场台之官以祀之。 宋玉作《神女赋》以寓情荒淫，托辞秽芜，高真上仙岂可诬而降之也。 《庄子》：藐姑射之山有神人居焉，肌肤若冰雪，掉约若处子，不食五谷，吸风饮露，乘云气，御飞龙，而游乎四海之外。 元嘉六举，素卿三绝。 《朝野会载》：唐元嘉少聪俊，左手画圆，右手画方，口诵经史，目数韦羊，兼成四十字诗，一时而就，足书一绝，六事齐举，时号神仙童子。 《实宾录》五代蜀道士张素卿画献神仙十二轴，欧阳炯为赞，水部员外郎皇居东八分题之，号三绝。 乐巴斩狸，长房诃鳌。 《神仙传》：乐巴闻庐山庙有神与人语於帐中，巴未到十数日，庙中神不复作声，遂逃，不知所在。 巴自行逐·捕鬼，乃化为书生到齐，齐太守见其姿容妖丽，又有才辩，乃峡女妻之，生一男。 巴到齐，谒太守：闻卿有好女，婿明於五经，可得见否。 太守遂令婿出，婿拒辞不出，巴求之不已，婿告妇曰：今日出叉死，如之何。 女怪之。 巴知其不出，乃以符付太守，婿得符涕泣而去，巴厉声诃之，为狸，遂斩其头。 子亦化狸，并杀之矣。 又，费长房为市橡，遇壶公得道，能治鬼。 汝南郡中常岁鬼怪每来，时导从威仪如太守入府，打鼓周行，及去甚悲。 后长房诣府而正值此鬼，长房厉声呼使捉来，鬼乃下车叩头，乞得自改，长房呵曰：不念温良，无故导从唐突郡守，复汝真形。 须突成一大氅，长房令持符送与葛陕君，流涕而去。 使人追视之，至陂鳌死矣。 雷剑冲斗，尧查贯月。 《晋书》：斗牛之问有紫气，雷焕曰：宝剑之精，上彻於天。 云在豫章丰城，乃掘狱屋基，入地四丈，得石函中有双剑，一日龙泉，二日太阿。 焕得剑，送一与张华，一自佩。 及华诛，失剑所在。
chunks.translated_text:
Wang the Elder threshes wheat, Zhang Ji cracks the melon.

*The Biographies of Divine Transcendents* states: Wang the Elder was a native of Yijun County in Fangzhou. Dwelling in the countryside, he was deeply fond of the Dao and cherished guests. One day, a ragged Daoist arrived at his door. Wang and his wife received him with courtesy. After staying for over a month, the Daoist suddenly broke out in foul sores all over his body. Wang sought physicians and tended to him with increasing diligence, but the Daoist said, “No need for medicine—just prepare several *hu* of fine wine, and I will soak in it to heal myself.” Wang then brewed the wine. When it was ready, the Daoist ordered it stored in a large jar, added medicine, and immersed himself within. After two days, he emerged with hair and beard turned black, his complexion restored to youth, his skin smooth as congealed lard. He then bade Wang drink it. At the time, Wang was threshing wheat, so he shared the wine with his wife, children, and fellow laborers. All grew deeply drunk. The Daoist drank as well, asking, “Would you like to ascend to heaven?” Suddenly, an auspicious wind arose, and colorful clouds billowed forth. The entire household—people, chickens, and dogs—flew away together, the sound of threshing wheat still lingering in the air. Today, the village of Shengxian remains west of Yijun County.

*The Miscellaneous Records of Yang Wen* recounts: Zhang Ji lived outside the city walls when a recluse—none other than the immortal Lü Dongbin—visited him. Zhang received him with utmost reverence. The immortal asked for paper and brush, writing a seven-character poem in clerical script, leaving it for Zhang. The verses hinted at the fleeting nature of high office and prestige, concluding: *“Success will come in the year you crack the melon.”* The common folk interpret “cracking the melon” as the age of sixteen (two eights), but Zhang indeed lived to sixty-eight, proving the immortal’s foresight.

Clouds and rain of Mount Wu, ice and snow of Guye.

*The Collected Records of Transcendents* states: The Lady Yunhua was the twenty-third daughter of the Queen Mother of the West, named Yaoji. Once, while traveling to the Eastern Sea, she passed by the Yangtze River and came upon Mount Wu, where peaks and ridges soared, forests and ravines lay in serene beauty, and a massive stone resembled an altar. She lingered there for a long time. At that moment, the Great Yu was controlling the floods and had halted at the mountain’s base. A sudden gale arose, shaking cliffs and valleys, its force uncontrollable. Yu encountered Yaoji and bowed, beseeching her aid. She commanded her attendants to bestow upon Yu a talisman to summon spirits, then ordered her divine servants to assist him in cleaving rocks and dredging waves, blocking side channels to preserve the main flow. Yu later visited her at Chongyao, but in the blink of an eye, she transformed into stone. At times, she would swiftly ascend, scattering into light clouds; at others, she would linger, gathering into evening rain. Sometimes she became a flying dragon, or a soaring crane—assuming a thousand forms in ten thousand postures, untouchable and elusive. Later, the Chu minister Song Yu spoke of her to King Xiang, but the king, unable to seek the essence of the Dao for immortality, built a terrace at the Gaotang Palace and established the Changtai Temple to worship her. Song Yu composed *The Rhapsody of the Divine Woman*, imbuing it with licentious sentiment and base rhetoric, wrongly dragging down a lofty transcendent.

*Zhuangzi* states: On the distant Guye Mountain dwells a divine being. Her skin is like ice and snow, her demeanor supple as a maiden’s. She eats no grain, drinking only wind and dew. She rides the clouds and qi, driving flying dragons, roaming beyond the four seas.

Yuan Jia’s six feats, Suqing’s three perfections.

*The Court and Countryside Gatherings* records: In the Tang dynasty, Yuan Jia was a youth of extraordinary intelligence. With his left hand, he drew circles; with his right, squares. While reciting classics and histories, he counted sheep’s vertebrae, simultaneously composing a forty-character poem—all accomplished in an instant. With his foot, he wrote a perfect verse. These six feats performed at once earned him the title “Divine Child of the Immortals.”

*The Records of Verified Worthies* states: During the Five Dynasties, the Shu Daoist Zhang Suqing painted twelve scrolls of divine transcendents. Ouyang Jiong composed eulogies, and Huang Judong inscribed them in clerical script. Together, they were hailed as the “Three Perfections.”

Le Ba beheads the fox-spirit, Changfang scolds the giant turtle.

*The Biographies of Divine Transcendents* states: Le Ba heard that the deity of the Lushan Temple spoke to people from behind a curtain. Before Ba arrived, the deity fell silent for over ten days, then vanished without a trace. Ba pursued and captured ghosts, transforming into a scholar who traveled to Qi. The governor of Qi, struck by his striking beauty and eloquence, married his daughter to him. They had a son. When Ba arrived in Qi, he visited the governor, saying, “I hear you have a fine daughter, and her husband is well-versed in the Five Classics. May I meet him?” The governor summoned his son-in-law, who refused to appear. Ba persisted until the son-in-law told his wife, “If I go out today, I will die. What shall I do?” She found this strange. Knowing he would not emerge, Ba gave the governor a talisman. The son-in-law received it, wept, and departed. Ba rebuked him sternly, and he transformed into a fox. Ba beheaded him, and his son also turned into a fox, both slain.

Furthermore, Fei Changfang served as a market inspector when he met the Venerable Hu, gaining the Dao and the power to subdue ghosts. In Runan Commandery, ghosts often appeared each year, parading with the pomp of a governor, drums sounding as they circled the prefecture before departing in sorrow. Later, Changfang visited the prefectural office and encountered one such ghost. He shouted sternly, ordering it seized. The ghost dismounted, kowtowed, and begged for a chance to reform. Changfang scolded, “You show no kindness, recklessly parading before the prefect. Return to your true form!” Instantly, it became a giant soft-shelled turtle. Changfang commanded it to take a talisman to the Lord of Ge Marsh. It left in tears. Those sent to follow saw it reach the marsh and die.

Lei Jian’s sword pierces the Dipper, Yao Zha’s arrow pierces the moon.

*The Book of Jin* records: Between the Dipper and Ox constellations appeared a purple vapor. Lei Huan said, “This is the essence of a treasure sword, its brilliance reaching heaven.” He surmised the sword lay in Fengcheng of Yuzhang. Huan kept one and sent the other to Zhang Hua. After Hua’s execution, the swords vanished.

chunks.original_text: 及焕卒，其子众持剑行经延平津，忽於腰下跃出堕．水，使人入水，见两龙盘合光照水而去。 焕曾云：灵异之物终当化去。 果然。 《仙传拾遗》：尧登位三十年，有巨查浮於西海，查上有光，夜明昼灭。 海人望其光乍大乍小，若星月之出入矣。 查常浮绕四海，十二年一周天，周而复始，名日贯月查。 张哥呼蝶，初平叱羊。 《散仙传》：庆历间有张九哥者，在京师，有道卫。 燕王一日登楼上，命呼之，尝赐以酒，九哥曰：某有小侠，欲以悦王可乎。 王曰：何仗也。 九哥曰：借王帛一疋并金剪一柄。 王悉与之。 取罗碎剪为蜂蝶状，随剪皆飞去，莫知其数，或集王衣，或聚美人钗锻上，王惊顾大喜，九哥曰：恐失王之帛。 乃呼之，一一皆来，复为罗。 一端罗中间一缺似一蝶之痕，乃一蝶为官人所捕也。 王曰：此一蝶可复归乎。 曰：不可也，若随呼而来即可，既久即已亦留此为异也。 乃别去。 《神仙传》：黄初平家使牧羊，有道士将入金华山不归，兄初起求之不得，后於市中见一道士，问之，道士曰：金华山下一牧羊小兄非是耶。 初起随道士往见其弟，问羊何在，初平曰：羊在山束。 起往视之，但见白石，初平叱之，白石皆化为羊。 顺兴辟戎，进贤骂羌。 《丹台新录》：李顺兴年十一与道士籍，一日有飞仙千数集空中，神光照室，命侍经仙郎开九色流霞之蕴，出经二卷以授之。 魏文帝尝召入都城，朝野钦信，称为李炼师。 年三十八，大统六年，托疾告终。 葬日，有侄遇於骊山道中，谓曰：若天子尚未忘我，则可於此作吾像，北向居之，当为国家辟北戎之淫俗也。 侄还家，方知已化，遂以实奏。 遣使发视，则空棺而已，乃立祠於沙苑，号李圣。 《真诰》：王衍为晋武帝尚书令，其女字进贤，为愍怀太子妃。 洛阳陷，刘曜、石勒掠进贤渡孟津，於河中欲妻之，进贤骂曰：我皇太子妇，司徒公之女，而胡羌小子，敢干我乎。 言毕即投河中，其侍婢名六出，复言曰：大既有之，小亦宜然。 复投河中。 时遇嵩高女真韩西华出游而愍之，抚接二人，遂获内救，外示死形，体实密济，便将入嵩高山，令在华阳官洞中易迁之官。 六出时年二十二三，体貌亦整善，有心节，本姓田，渔阳人，魏故浚仪令田讽之孙。 讽曾有阴德之行，以及六出耳。 孟钦风旋，丘林云翔。 《晋逸史》：孟钦得左慈、刘根之法，百姓归向之。 时符坚恶其惑众，欲诛之。 俄而钦至，坚留之。 饮酒酣，令左右执之，钦化为旋风而去。 有告在城东，忽前汉水不能渡。 《真诰》：范丘林在华阳官为保命丞，善长啸，如百鸟之杂呜，或如风激众林，或如伐鼓之音，须臾云翔其上，冲气动林。 休复妓侮，徐姑僧僵。 《仙传拾遗》：陈休复者，号陈七子，尝於巴南太守筵中为酒妓所侮，休复笑视其面，须突妓者髯长数尺，泣诉於守。 守为析谢，休复呢一枉酒使饮之，良久如旧。 《广记》：徐仙姑者，北齐仆射徐之才之女也，年数百岁，状貌常如二十四五岁。 善禁呢之卫，名山胜景无不周游，多宿岩麓之中。 寓止僧院，忽为豪僧数辈微辞巧言侮之，姑马之，韦僧激怒，色愈悖，姑笑曰：我女子也，而能弃家云水，不避蛟龙虎狼，岂惧汝鼠辈乎。
chunks.translated_text:
When Huan died, his son Chong carried the sword and passed by Yanping Ford. Suddenly, it leapt from his waist and fell into the water. Divers sent to retrieve it saw two dragons coiled together, their radiance illuminating the water as they departed. Huan had once said, “Such numinous and wondrous things must eventually transform and depart.” Indeed, it came to pass.

*The Gleamings of Immortal Biographies* records: In the thirtieth year of Yao’s reign, a giant raft floated upon the Western Sea. Upon the raft shone a light that gleamed by night and faded by day. Those who dwelt by the sea observed its glow waxing and waning like the rising and setting of stars and moon. The raft perpetually circled the Four Seas, completing one revolution of the heavens every twelve years, returning to its starting point without end. It was named the Moon-Piercing Raft.

Zhang Ge calls butterflies; Chuping commands sheep.

*The Biographies of Scattered Immortals* states: During the Qingli era, there lived a man named Zhang Jiuge in the capital, who possessed the arts of the Dao. One day, the Prince of Yan ascended a tower and summoned him. After bestowing wine upon him, Jiuge said, “I have a small marvel I wish to present to Your Highness.” The prince asked, “What trick is this?” Jiuge replied, “I require a bolt of silk and a pair of golden scissors.” The prince provided them. Jiuge took the silk, cut it into shapes of bees and butterflies, and with each snip, they took flight—countless in number. Some alighted upon the prince’s robes, others clustered upon the hairpins and ornaments of his beauties. The prince, astonished and delighted, turned to gaze in wonder. Jiuge said, “I fear Your Highness may lose some of your silk.” He then called to them, and one by one, they returned, reassembling into the bolt of silk. Only one section remained incomplete, marked by the trace of a butterfly—one had been caught by a palace attendant. The prince asked, “Can this butterfly be restored?” Jiuge replied, “It cannot. Had it returned at my call, it would have been possible. But now, too much time has passed, and it shall remain here as a marvel.” With that, he took his leave.

*The Biographies of Divine Immortals* records: Huang Chuping was sent by his family to herd sheep. A Daoist took him into Golden Flower Mountain, and he never returned. His brother, Chuqi, searched for him in vain. Later, in the marketplace, he encountered a Daoist who asked, “Is that not the young shepherd from beneath Golden Flower Mountain?” Chuqi followed the Daoist to see his brother. When he asked where the sheep were, Chuping replied, “The sheep are east of the mountain.” Chuqi went to look but saw only white stones. Chuping shouted at them, and the stones all transformed into sheep.

Shunxing repels the Rong; Jinxian reviles the Qiang.

*The New Record of the Red Terrace* states: Li Shunxing, at the age of eleven, became a disciple of a Daoist. One day, thousands of flying immortals gathered in the sky above, their divine radiance illuminating the chamber. The Celestial Attendant of the Scriptures was commanded to open the repository of nine-colored flowing clouds, from which two scrolls were brought forth and bestowed upon him. Emperor Wen of Wei once summoned him to the capital, where both court and common folk revered and trusted him, calling him Master Li the Alchemist. At the age of thirty-eight, in the sixth year of the Datong era, he feigned illness and announced his passing. On the day of his burial, his nephew encountered him on the road to Mount Li and said, “If the Son of Heaven has not yet forgotten me, you may erect my image here, facing north, and I shall ward off the corrupt customs of the northern Rong for the nation.” His nephew returned home only to learn of his death. He reported the matter in full to the throne. Envoys were sent to exhume the coffin, but it was found empty. A shrine was then established in Shayuan, named the Sacred Li.

*The Declarations of the Perfected* records: Wang Yan served as President of the Secretariat under Emperor Wu of Jin, and his daughter, named Jinxian, was the consort of Crown Prince Minhuai. When Luoyang fell, Liu Yao and Shi Le abducted Jinxian and attempted to cross the Meng Ford. There, they sought to take her as a wife. Jinxian cursed them, saying, “I am the wife of the Crown Prince, daughter of the Minister of Works. How dare you, barbarian dogs, presume to touch me?” With these words, she threw herself into the river. Her maidservant, named Liuchu, then declared, “If the great one has done so, the lesser should follow.” She, too, leapt into the river. At that moment, the Female Perfected of Mount Song, Han Xihua, was traveling and took pity on them. She rescued the two, concealing their true fate while outwardly appearing as if they had perished. Their bodies were secretly preserved, and they were taken into Mount Song, where they were installed in the Grotto of Flourishing Yang to assume new ranks among the immortals. Liuchu was then twenty-two or twenty-three, of comely appearance and resolute character. Her original surname was Tian, and she hailed from Yuyang. She was the granddaughter of Tian Feng, former magistrate of Junyi during the Wei dynasty. Feng had once performed a hidden act of virtue, which extended to Liuchu.

Meng Qin’s whirlwind spins; Qiu Lin’s clouds soar.

*The Unofficial History of Jin* states: Meng Qin mastered the arts of Zuo Ci and Liu Gen, and the people flocked to him. The ruler Fu Jian, displeased by his sway over the masses, sought to execute him. Suddenly, Qin appeared before him. Jian detained him, and as they drank, the ruler ordered his attendants to seize him. Qin transformed into a whirlwind and departed. Someone reported he was east of the city, but when pursued, he was suddenly before the Han River, which could not be crossed.

*The Declarations of the Perfected* records: Fan Qiulin served as the Lifeguard Assistant in the Grotto of Flourishing Yang. Skilled in the art of whistling, his notes resembled the mingling of a hundred birds, now like the wind stirring the forest, now like the beat of drums. In an instant, clouds soared above him, and vital qi stirred the woods.

Xiu Fu’s vengeance on the dancing girl; Xu Gu’s wrath upon the lecherous monks.

*The Gleamings of Immortal Biographies* states: Chen Xiufu, known as Chen the Seventh Son, once attended a banquet hosted by the governor of Banan. There, a dancing girl insulted him. Xiufu merely smiled at her, and in an instant, the girl’s beard grew several feet long. She wept and complained to the governor, who apologized on her behalf. Xiufu then sipped a mouthful of wine and sprayed it upon her. After a long while, she returned to her former state. He then took his leave.

*The Extensive Records* states: Immortal Lady Xu was the daughter of Xu Zhicai, the Grand Preceptor of Northern Qi. Though she lived for several centuries, her appearance remained that of a woman of twenty-four or twenty-five. Skilled in the arts of restraint and incantation, she wandered all famous mountains and scenic landscapes, often lodging in the caves and foothills. Once, while staying at a monastery, she was subtly insulted by several arrogant monks with cunning words. The lady rebuked them, but the monks grew only more enraged. She laughed and said, “I am but a woman, yet I have abandoned home and family to roam the rivers and clouds, unafraid of dragons and tigers. How could I fear the likes of you, mere rats?”

chunks.original_text: 姑即解衣而外，遽彻其烛。 僧喜，以为得志。 泊明，姑理策出山，诸僧一夕皆僵立尸坐，口不能言。 姑去数里，僧乃如故。 淮南八公，田谷十老。 《神仙传》：淮南王刘安折节下士，有八公者诣其门，门吏曰：王上欲延寿命以期长生不老之道，今公皆老矣。 公曰：若王叉欲见少年谓之有道，谨以少矣。 言讫皆化为童子，色如桃花。 《高导传》：法师．严达字道通，幼有方外志，与王延、苏道标、程法明、周化生、王真微、史道乐、于长文、张法成、伏道崇等十人以道衍相忌，同於出处，世号十老。 赵升取桃，田师降枣。 《神仙传》：汉天师将诸弟子登云台绝岩之上，下有桃一株，如人臂傍，生石壁下，临不测之渊，桃大有实，天师谓诸弟子曰：有人能得此桃实，当告以道要。 於时伏而窥者二百余人，股战流汗，无敢久临视者，莫不却退而还，谢不能得。 升乃从上投掷木上，足不蹉跌，取桃实满怀。 天师乃分赐诸弟子。 后授以至一道，白日上升。

The lady then removed her outer garments and suddenly extinguished the candle. The monks rejoiced, believing they had gained the upper hand. By dawn, as the lady prepared her staff to depart the mountain, all the monks stood frozen in place like corpses, their mouths unable to speak. Only after she had gone several *li* did they return to normal.

The Eight Lords of Huainan and the Ten Elders of Tiangu.
*The Biographies of Divine Transcendents* states: King Liu An of Huainan humbled himself to honor scholars. Eight lords arrived at his gate, and the gatekeeper said, “His Highness seeks to extend his lifespan and attain the Dao of agelessness. Yet all of you are already old.” The lords replied, “If the king wishes to see youths and call them ‘possessors of the Dao,’ we shall oblige by becoming young.” With these words, they transformed into boys, their complexions like peach blossoms.

*The Biography of Master Gao*: The Dharma Master Yan Da, styled Daotong, harbored aspirations beyond the mundane from childhood. Together with Wang Yan, Su Daobiao, Cheng Faming, Zhou Huasheng, Wang Zhenwei, Shi Daole, Yu Changwen, Zhang Facheng, and Fu Daochong—ten men who vied in their mastery of the Dao and shared the same path—he was known to the world as the Ten Elders.

Zhao Sheng plucked the peach; the field master descended with jujubes.
*The Biographies of Divine Transcendents* states: The Han Celestial Master led his disciples to the summit of Cloud Terrace, a sheer cliff. Below grew a single peach tree, its branches like human arms, clinging to the stone wall above an unfathomable abyss. The peaches were large and ripe. The Celestial Master said to his disciples, “Whoever can retrieve these peaches shall be taught the essentials of the Dao.” Over two hundred disciples crouched to peer down, their legs trembling and sweat streaming, yet none dared linger. All retreated, claiming they could not do it. Only Zhao Sheng cast a wooden plank from above, stepped onto it without stumbling, and gathered an armful of peaches. The Celestial Master then divided them among the disciples. Later, he transmitted to Sheng the ultimate Dao, and Sheng ascended to the heavens in broad daylight.

chunks.original_text: 《高道传》：田法师者名仕文，古郎人也，授三洞经法，服饵炼气，斋戒修奉，未尝少辍。 每与人析福及救疾，无不通感，即获平愈。 陈纲尝请作醮，忽神降枣数颗在坛，食之则非人间所有者。 梦昌戴花，子韦被草。 《郡阁雅谈》：伊梦昌，不知何许人，因梦两日，遂立其名。 唐末不仕，披羽褐游山水散逸，爱载花。 又《青琐后集》：梦昌尝题攸县司空观仙坛云：唯有青松空弄日，更无云鹤暗迷人。 题黄蜀葵云：露凝金盏滴残酒，檀点佳人喷异香。 梦昌后尸解，人发其棺，无尸。 《太平广记》：宋景公之世有善星文者，许以上大夫之位。 处层楼延阁之上，以望气象，设以珍食，施以宝衣。 忽有野人被草负茨叩门而进，请见景公，公延之崇堂，语则及未来之兆，及已往之事，万不失一。 夜则观星气，昼则执算披图，不服宝衣，不甘奇食，景公谢曰：今国丧乱微君何以辅之。 曰：德之不均，乱将及矣。 修德以来人，则天条之祥，人美其化。 景公称善，遂赐姓日子，名之韦，即子韦也。 万传八音，韦赠三宝。 《仙传拾遗》：万宝常者，不知何许人也，幼达音律，因於郊中遇十许人，车服鲜丽，麾幢森列，召之上帝以子天授音律之性，将传八音於季世，故将坏之乐然正始之音，子未备知也。 命坐，乃教以历代之乐，治乱之音，靡不周迷。 宝常毕记之，由是韦仙凌空而去。 宝常自此人问之乐无不精究。 《神仙感应传》：韦拿字景昭，因下第，游蜀至郑氏园亭，见仙子数十，左右侍卫，华裙丽服，非世所赌，谓予有新曲，名日紫云，今天子奉尚神仙之道，吾欲以此乐授与吾子而贡於圣唐之君，以此相托可乎。 食某儒生耳，素非知音，固不可为也。 美人既不能，余当寓梦以授於天子也。 然子已至此，亦道分使然，愿以三宝为赠，其售之可以毕世而富。 命侍者出一杯，谓之碧瑶杯，又出一枕，似玉而粟其纹，又出一紫玉函，皆光彩莹彻，俱受於拿，拜而谢之，即别去。 回顾，失向亭台矣。 叔隐仙伯，周颛鬼官。 《丹台新录》：秦叔隐今在华山为仙伯。 《真语》：周颤为鬼官司帅。 注云：周颠字伯仁，汝南安城人，仕晋，过江，位至尚书仆射。 元帝永昌元年，王敦南下，遣收於石头南门被害，年五十四岁，追赠光禄开府，镒康侯。 贾耽偷书，神通窃丹。 《逸史》：贾就一日令健卒入枯井中取文书，果得数轴，皆道书也。 遂遣十余人写才毕，有道士突入，呼贾公姓名叫骂争敢偷书。 耽逊谢，道士复持去。 《高道传》：辅神通幼孤贫，为人牧牛以自给，每於牧所见一道士往来，久而稔熟，谓神通能为弟子乎。 日：可。 乃引入水。
